image.altText: Army forces are pictured walking through a street, heavily armed.

items.synopsis: The Israeli Defence Forces say they're fighting at "about seven or eight" locations near Gaza in an attempt to "establish security". Follow live.

title.children: Israel is working 'to establish security' as 100,000 reservists gather at Gaza border

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're getting some new lines out of Israel that answer some of the lingering questions we've had about the situation on the ground. We'll bring you more information when we have it, but in summary, the Israeli Defence Forces has said: Israel is still fighting 'at about seven to eight' locations near Gaza Some Hamas 'infiiltrators' are still able to enter Israel The military believes 'dozens' of Israelis are being held captive in Gaza Four 'combat divisions' have been deployed to southern Israel, but it's taking longer than expected to 'establish security' Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel is still working to 'establish security'

children.content: We're getting some new lines out of Israel that answer some of the lingering questions we've had about the situation on the ground.
We'll bring you more information when we have it, but in summary, the Israeli Defence Forces has said:
Israel is still fighting 'at about seven to eight' locations near Gaza
Some Hamas 'infiiltrators' are still able to enter Israel
The military believes 'dozens' of Israelis are being held captive in Gaza
Four 'combat divisions' have been deployed to southern Israel, but it's taking longer than expected to 'establish security'
Israel has deployed combat units and reservists to the border region.
(Reuters: Ammar Awad)
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Akram Al Satarri lives in Gaza with his family and said he works as a journalist. He told ABC Radio Melbourne earlier today he believed the conflict was different this time. "We have lived a very long time under occupation," he said. "The way the Palestinian resistance factions are moving ... the way they are dealing with the Israeli army, it shows some dynamics are changing. "It shows some sort of solution must be found to find a just solution for the chronic crisis and bottlenecks that the people of Gaza and Palestine have been living." Mr Al Satarri said the bodies of people he knew were being retrieved from the rubble from strikes on Gaza. "I don't think anyone in Gaza is safe. There are no guarantees anyone in Gaza will survive," he said. "The sounds of explosions are everywhere – wherever you go, you will hear them." He said there was already a severe shortage of food, with the Israeli government blocking supplies from reaching the Gaza Strip after the attack by Hamas.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Some dynamics are changing': Report from inside Gaza

children.content: Akram Al Satarri lives in Gaza with his family and said he works as a journalist.
He told ABC Radio Melbourne earlier today he believed the conflict was different this time.
"We have lived a very long time under occupation," he said.
"The way the Palestinian resistance factions are moving ... the way they are dealing with the Israeli army, it shows some dynamics are changing.
"It shows some sort of solution must be found to find a just solution for the chronic crisis and bottlenecks that the people of Gaza and Palestine have been living."
Mr Al Satarri said the bodies of people he knew were being retrieved from the rubble from strikes on Gaza.
"I don't think anyone in Gaza is safe. There are no guarantees anyone in Gaza will survive," he said.
"The sounds of explosions are everywhere – wherever you go, you will hear them."
He said there was already a severe shortage of food, with the Israeli government blocking supplies from reaching the Gaza Strip after the attack by Hamas.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There are 100,000 Israeli reserve troops gathered in southern Israel "preparing to execute the task that the Israeli Government has designated the Israeli military to do", according to IDF spokesperson Jonathan Conricus. In a video posted to the IDF X account, Conricus said: "Our job is to make sure that at the end of this war, Hamas will no longer have any military capability to threatens Israelis civilians with." "And in addition to that, we are to also make sure Hamas will not be able to govern the Gaza Strip." Yesterday, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said his security cabinet had made the decision to destroy Hamas’s ability to govern in a way that posed a threat to Israeli civilians.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel amasses 100,000 reservists in Gaza border region: IDF spokesperson

children.content: There are 100,000 Israeli reserve troops gathered in southern Israel "preparing to execute the task that the Israeli Government has designated the Israeli military to do", according to IDF spokesperson Jonathan Conricus.
In a video posted to the IDF X account, Conricus said: "Our job is to make sure that at the end of this war, Hamas will no longer have any military capability to threatens Israelis civilians with."
"And in addition to that, we are to also make sure Hamas will not be able to govern the Gaza Strip."
Yesterday, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said his security cabinet had made the decision to destroy Hamas’s ability to govern in a way that posed a threat to Israeli civilians.

image.altText: Two election placard - one for yes, one for no

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: More than 2.2 million Australians cast early votes in the Voice referendum as Yes campaigners feel the pinch

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Isabella Higgins Redfern in Sydney's inner-city has a long history of Aboriginal activism and leadership. Today, community leaders met at the "The Block," a significant area in the neighbourhood, to rally support for the Yes vote. Shane Phillips is one of the well-known elders from Redfern, having helped create a number of social welfare programs that have transformed the community's relationship with police and authorities. He fronted the event with two of his grandchildren and said the nation needed this change. "I know why I'm voting yes because I see people in this community here, we were a community that were downtrodden and were actually imploding as a community for a long time from the scars of dispossession," he passionately told the crowd. "But we empowered ourselves, we found the solution, it was within us, we rebuilt ourselves, we went through healing. "That is all this Voice is about for us, we want that to happen so we can heal as a country, so we can empower ourselves, so, my granddaughter and our kids don't have to have this industry of closing the gap as something they inherit."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Community leaders rally support for the Yes vote in Redfern

children.content: Reporting by Isabella Higgins
Redfern
in Sydney's inner-city has a long history of Aboriginal activism and leadership.
Today, community leaders met at the "The Block," a significant area in the neighbourhood, to rally support for the Yes vote.

props.alt: A crowd of Yes campaigners pose for a photo in front of the mural that reads 'Welcome to Redfern'.

children.content: (ABC News: Isabella Higgins)
Shane Phillips
is one of the well-known elders from Redfern, having helped create a number of social welfare programs that have transformed the community's relationship with police and authorities.
He fronted the event with two of his grandchildren and said the nation needed this change.

props.alt: A Yes rally walks the street holding Vote Yes signs.

children.content: (ABC News: Isabella Higgins)

"I know why I'm voting yes because I see people in this community here, we were a community that were downtrodden and were actually imploding as a community for a long time from the scars of dispossession," he passionately told the crowd.
"But we empowered ourselves, we found the solution, it was within us, we rebuilt ourselves, we went through healing.

"That is all this Voice is about for us, we want that to happen so we can heal as a country, so we can empower ourselves, so, my granddaughter and our kids don't have to have this industry of closing the gap as something they inherit."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you can't make it to a polling place this Saturday, October 14, then don't fret - the AEC has confirmed that early voting places will be open until Friday. They also shared some stats on how voting looks so far: 2,212,581 people have voted at an early voting centre. This compares to 2 million at the same stage of the 2022 federal election. 1,945,823 people have applied for a postal vote so far. This compares to 2.5 million at the same stage of the 2022 federal election. 92,162 people have voted via an AEC mobile polling team. This includes 19,194 in remote communities. Other mobile polling includes aged care facilities, mental health facilities and prisons. Click here to find an early voting centre near you.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Early voting centres will be open until Friday, says AEC

children.content: Hundreds of early voting centres are open around the country.
(Supplied: AEC)

This compares to 2 million at the same stage of the 2022 federal election.

This compares to 2.5 million at the same stage of the 2022 federal election.

This includes 19,194 in remote communities.
Other mobile polling includes aged care facilities, mental health facilities and prisons.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A prominent Yes campaigner says if the referendum fails, it will be a "travesty for the country". On Saturday, Australians will be asked whether they support enshrining the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice in the constitution. The majority of polls suggest the referendum will not be successful. Noel Pearson, who is one of the architects of the Uluru Statement of the Heart, which put forward the Voice to Parliament, says that outcome would be disappointing. "This is a moral choice for the country, not just a question of constitutional law," he told AM. "The choice we have is not equivalent - Yes and No are not equivalent choices. "Yes is of a different quality to No. No would be a travesty for the country." You can listen to the full interview on AM with Sabra Lane by taping the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Noel Pearson says Australia will never live down a 'No' vote

featuredLink.title: Noel Pearson says Australia will never live down a 'No' vote - ABC listen

props.alt: A close up of Noel speaking.

children.content: Noel Pearson.
(AAP: Lukas Coch)
A prominent Yes campaigner says if the referendum fails, it will be a "travesty for the country".

The majority of polls suggest the referendum will not be successful.
Noel Pearson
, who is one of the architects of the Uluru Statement of the Heart, which put forward the Voice to Parliament, says that outcome would be disappointing.
"This is a moral choice for the country, not just a question of constitutional law," he told

"The choice we have is not equivalent - Yes and No are not equivalent choices.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX has finished higher for the day, up 0.2% to 6,790 points. It was a solid day of gains for energy stocks, helped by higher oil prices after the Hamas attack. Looking at the sectors, energy picked up 3%, followed by healthcare (+0.8%) and academic and educational services (+0.5%). There were modest gains for basic materials (+0.2%) and utilities (+0.2%). Consumer cyclicals saw a 0.1% rise, while industrials was flat. There were four sectors in the red: consumer non-cyclicals (-0.4%), real estate (-0.3%), technology (-0.2%) and financials (-0.1%). The best performers of the day were (unsurprisingly) mostly gold miners, buoyed by higher bullion prices: De Grey Mining +8.1% Silver Lake Resources +6.3% Evolution Mining +6.3% West African Resources +6% Karoon Energy +5.7% And the worst performers of the day: Weebit Nano -9% Magellan Financial -7.2% Pilbara Minerals -4.6% Qantas Airways -3.8% Sayona Mining -3.4%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX closes higher after energy and gold stocks rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In response to the Financial Sector Union's claims that the Commonwealth Bank is reducing its workforce by 192 jobs, the bank says it is working closely with those affected to help them find "other opportunities". It says it doesn't take the decision to reduce roles "lightly", and is focused on supporting those who are impacted. Here's the statement from a CBA spokesman in full: "CBA employs around 50,000 people across Australia and internationally and since 2021 we have recruited more than 10,000 people, reinforcing our position as one of Australia's largest employers. "As part of our focus on constant business improvement, we regularly review the skills we need and how we organised. That means from time to time some roles and work will change or no longer be required. "These decisions are never easy nor are they taken lightly. "Our priority is to treat every individual with respect and care, taking time to talk with each employee impacted to understand individual circumstances and work with them on finding opportunities and building skills to support them for another role in or outside the bank."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Commonwealth Bank says it's supporting those impacted by job cuts to find other roles

children.content: In response to the Financial Sector Union's claims that the Commonwealth Bank is reducing its workforce by 192 jobs, the bank says it is working closely with those affected to help them find "other opportunities".
It says it doesn't take the decision to reduce roles "lightly", and is focused on supporting those who are impacted.
Here's the statement from a CBA spokesman in full:
"CBA employs around 50,000 people across Australia and internationally and since 2021 we have recruited more than 10,000 people, reinforcing our position as one of Australia's largest employers.

"As part of our focus on constant business improvement, we regularly review the skills we need and how we organised. That means from time to time some roles and work will change or no longer be required.
"These decisions are never easy nor are they taken lightly.

"Our priority is to treat every individual with respect and care, taking time to talk with each employee impacted to understand individual circumstances and work with them on finding opportunities and building skills to support them for another role in or outside the bank."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to the report from the Senate inquiry, which notes that the federal government has suggested no less than 12 different reasons for denying Qatar Airways' additional flight requests. The final report released by the Senate committee this afternoon includes those 12 reasons, which range from human rights, local jobs, protecting the industry, and an already competitive aviation environment. Here's the full list of reasons included in the final report: Human rights (in response to the invasive strip searches of women at Doha Airport) Decarbonising the aviation sector Protecting Australian jobs Qantas' recent purchase of new planes The threat to the domestic aviation industry Not in the 'national interest' Qatar Airways' unused access Applications from other airlines to increase capacity The aviation market is already competitive What's happening with the domestic and international aviation market at the moment What's happening with the COVID recovery What's happening with capacity returning to the market If you want to read the full report, you can do so here .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal government has put forward 'at least 12' arguments for rejecting Qatar flights

children.content: That's according to the report from the Senate inquiry, which notes that the federal government has suggested no less than 12 different reasons for denying Qatar Airways' additional flight requests.

The final report released by the Senate committee this afternoon includes those 12 reasons, which range from human rights, local jobs, protecting the industry, and an already competitive aviation environment.
Here's the full list of reasons included in the final report:
Human rights (in response to the invasive strip searches of women at Doha Airport)
Decarbonising the aviation sector
Protecting Australian jobs
Qantas' recent purchase of new planes
The threat to the domestic aviation industry
Not in the 'national interest'
Qatar Airways' unused access
Applications from other airlines to increase capacity
The aviation market is already competitive
What's happening with the domestic and international aviation market at the moment
What's happening with the COVID recovery
What's happening with capacity returning to the market
If you want to read the full report,
you can do so here

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The AFL says it has received and approved the required paperwork to make Todd Goldstein a Bomber as an unrestricted free agent. North Melbourne won't get anything back from the AFL for this one.

The AFL says it has received and approved the required paperwork to make Todd Goldstein a Bomber as an unrestricted free agent.
North Melbourne won't get anything back from the AFL for this one.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to Peter Ryan from The Age, who reports that Duursma is set to formally request a trade to the Bombers. I personally would absolutely love to see a neat and tidy player-for-player deal get done here that sends Duursma to Essendon and Brandon Zerk-Thatcher to Port Adelaide. Seems pretty fair for all parties I'd say, and lets both sides keep their draft capital for other deals.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Xavier Duursma reportedly wants Essendon move

children.content: (Getty Images)
That's according to Peter Ryan from The Age, who reports that Duursma is set to formally request a trade to the Bombers.

I personally would absolutely love to see a neat and tidy player-for-player deal get done here that sends Duursma to Essendon and Brandon Zerk-Thatcher to Port Adelaide. Seems pretty fair for all parties I'd say, and lets both sides keep their draft capital for other deals.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some breaking news coming through this afternoon. It is being reported by Channel 7's Mitch Cleary and SEN's Sam Edmund that Fremantle small forward Lachie Schultz has requested a trade to Collingwood. Pretty big news, Schultz is a great little player. The Pies are pretty stocked for small forwards, but when players of Schultz's quality become available you have to make a move. But geez, if Freo want the world for Liam Henry, imagine what they'll ask for for Lachie Schultz ...
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lachie Schultz has reportedly requested a trade to Collingwood

children.content: (Getty Images)
Some breaking news coming through this afternoon.
It is being reported by Channel 7's Mitch Cleary and SEN's Sam Edmund that Fremantle small forward Lachie Schultz has requested a trade to Collingwood.
Pretty big news, Schultz is a great little player. The Pies are pretty stocked for small forwards, but when players of Schultz's quality become available you have to make a move.
But geez, if Freo want the world for Liam Henry, imagine what they'll ask for for Lachie Schultz ...
